facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 704 to 715 of 1963 are appeals from judgments and orders dated March 17, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax References Nos. 41, 42, 43, 57, 58, 59, 69, and 77 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 704 to 715 of 1963. Appeals from the judgments and orders dated March 17. 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No,,. 41, 42, 43, 57, 58, 5 9, 69, and 77 of 1957.

facts.text: The High Court of Bombay delivered judgments dated March 17, 1958, answering questions partly in favour of the assessee and partly in favour of the Department.

anchor.surface_text: This judgment will dispose of 12 appeals from the judgments of the High Court of Bombay, dated March 17, 1958, whereby the High Court answered the questions referred to it partly in favour of the assessee and partly in favour of the Department.

facts.text: Shri Purshottamdas Thakurdass (Assessee A) was a shareholder in Narandas Rajaram, Ltd., which carries on business both in India and Pakistan with profits accrued in both.

anchor.surface_text: It will be convenient to give the facts in the case of the assessee, the late Shri Purshottamdas Thakurdass, hereinafter referred to as Assessee A. He was a shareholder in Narandas Rajaram, Ltd., which carries on business both in India and Pakistan.

facts.text: Portion of dividend attributable to profits accrued in Pakistan amounted to Rs. 2,722 for Assessee A for assessment year 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: Profits accrued to it both in India and Pakistan. The company declared dividend out of the above profits. In the case of Assessee A, the portion of the dividend attributable to the profits that accrued in Pakistan amounted to Rs. 2,722 for the assessment year 1949-50.

facts.text: On May 20, 1952, the Income Tax Officer included Rs. 2,722 in Assessee A's total income for 1949-50 but held no income tax or super-tax payable on it.

anchor.surface_text: On May 20, 1952, the I.T.O. included this sum of Rs. 2,722 in the total income but held that no income tax or super-tax was payable in respect of this amount.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer reopened assessment of 1949-50 for Assessee A due to order under s.23A on Industrial Corporation Ltd., deeming Rs. 579 to accrue to him.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer reopened the assessment of 1949-50 because Assessee A was a shareholder in Industrial Corporation Ltd., and an order had been passed under s. 23A of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 hereinafter referred to as the Act in respect of this Corporation.

facts.text: In re-assessment order dated January 17, 1955, Income Tax Officer charged Rs. 579 and Rs. 2,722 to tax for Assessee A.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this order, Rs. 579 was deemed to have accrued to him. But in his re-assessment order, dated January 17, 1955, the Income Tax Officer brought to charge not only the said Rs. 579 but also the said sum of Rs. 2,722, i.e., the Pakistan portion of the dividend received from Narandas Rajaram Ltd.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the assessment order in respect of Rs. 579 and Rs. 2,722 for Assessee A.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the assessment order both in respect of Rs. 579 and Rs. 2,722.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal upheld the assessment order for Rs. 579 and Rs. 2,722 and referred first three questions to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal also upheld the order. The Appellate Tribunal then referred the first three questions to the High Court but refused to refer the following question...

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated March 17, 1958 answered the three questions against Assessee A.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by its judgment dated March 17, 1958, answered the three questions against the Assessee.

facts.text: High Court directed Appellate Tribunal to refer the supplementary question which Tribunal had declined.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also directed the Appellate Tribunal to refer the above question hereinafter to be referred to as the Supplementary Question which the Appellate Tribunal had declined to refer.

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated April 14, 1960 answered the supplementary question in favour of Assessee A.

anchor.surface_text: On the Appellate Tribunal referring the said question, the High Court by its judgment dated April 14, 1960, answered the question in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: On February 7, 1961, High Court granted certificate to Assessee A; Commissioner of Income Tax did not appeal against the April 14, 1960 judgment.

anchor.surface_text: On February 7, 1961, the High Court granted the necessary certificate to Assessee A. The Commissioner of Income Tax, however, did not appeal against the judgment of the High Court on the supplementary question.

facts.text: For assessment year 1952-53, net dividend received by Assessee A from Narandas Rajaram Ltd. was Rs. 1,12,867, of which Rs. 23,167 attributable to Pakistan profits charged to tax.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1952-53, the net dividend received by Assessee A from Narandas Rajaram Co., Ltd. was Rs. 1,12,867 out of which Rs. 23,167 was attributable to the profits of that company which accrued in Pakistan.

facts.text: High Court on July 10, 1959 granted certificate of fitness under s.66A(2) for 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on July 10, 1959, granted the certificate of fitness under S. 66A 2 of the Act.

facts.text: On October 14, 1952, Narandas Rajaram Co. Ltd. adopted resolution at ordinary general meeting declaring dividends including 32% on Ordinary Shares and additional 13% on B Preference Shares, with one moiety payable on/after Oct 16, 1952 and other within 2 months after remittances from Pakistan free.

anchor.surface_text: On October 14, 1952, the following resolution was adopted at the ordinary general meeting of Narandas Rajaram Co. Ltd. Dividends, as mentioned below, be and are hereby declared out of the profits of the Company A dividend of 4 per cent on A Preference Shares and 4 per cent on B Preference Shares.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer included entire Rs. 1,71,992 dividend in Assessee A's total income for assessment year 1953-54; confirmed by AAC and Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer included the entire amount of Rs. 1,71,992 in the total income of Assessee A. Both the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Appellate Tribunal confirmed this.

facts.text: High Court answered question D in the negative against Commissioner of Income Tax for 1953-54 and granted certificates under s.66A(2) to both Assessee A and CIT.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered question D in the negative i.e. against the Commissioner of Income Tax and the others, as in the others references, against the assessee. The High Court granted certificates under s. 66A 2 of the Act both to the Assessee A and the Commissioner of Income Tax.

facts.text: Facts in cases of other assessees are similar apart from amount of dividend involved.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to give the facts in the cases of other assessees for, apart from the amount of dividend involved, the facts are similar.

facts.text: Initiation of action under section 34 for Rs. 579 is academic as common ground due to Commissioner not appealing April 14, 1960 judgment.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to discuss the first question, which raises the point of the validity of proceedings under s. 34 of the Act, because it is common ground that it has become academic.

facts.text: Pakistan portion of dividend forms part of assessee's total income as per s.2(15); conceded by counsel.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the second question, Mr. Viswanatha Sastri rightly concedes that the Pakistan portion of the dividend forms part of the assessees total income, as defined in s. 2 15 of the Act.

facts.text: No certificate of assessment from the other Dominion produced before Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: it is common ground that no certificate of assessment in the other Dominion has been produced before the Income Tax Officer.

facts.text: Company's profit and loss account debited Rs. 5,85,000 for total dividend declared, with credits to Dividend Account Rs.5,74,144 etc.

anchor.surface_text: He said that the profit and loss Account of the Company was debited with Rs. 5,85,000, that being the total amount of dividend declared. The corresponding credits, he points out, were given as follows To seventh Dividend Account being the amount payable to shareholders Rs. 5,74,144-4-0

facts.text: Seventh dividend account showed credit balance of Rs. 2,92,500 representing unpaid moiety.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, after making payment, the seventh dividend account showed a credit balance of Rs. 2,92,500 representing a moiety of the dividend that remained to be paid out of the total dividend declared of Rs. 5,85,000.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds all appeals fail.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, all the appeals fail.

arguments.claim: The Pakistan portion of the dividend forms part of the assessee's total income as defined in s. 2(15) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the second question, Mr. Viswanatha Sastri rightly concedes that the Pakistan portion of the dividend forms part of the assessees total income, as defined in s. 2 15 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court followed precedent in Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Shanti K. Maheshwari; we hold High Court was right

arguments.claim: On true interpretation of Indo-Pakistan Agreement, each Dominion entitled to charge only proportion of income allotted to it under the Agreement

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri contends that on the true interpretation of the agreement each Dominion is entitled to charge only on the proportion of income allotted to it under the Agreement.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ce of double taxation of income was entered into between the Government of the Dominion of India and the Government of the Dominion of Pakistan. The f

arguments.court_reasoning: Art. IV allows assessment in ordinary way under own laws regardless of Agreement; restriction only on retaining tax via abatement on excess per Schedule; abatement ceases without certificate from other Dominion

arguments.claim: Each Dominion entitled to assess assessee on total income in normal way but allow abatement subject to conditions in Agreement being satisfied

anchor.surface_text: The reply on behalf of the Revenue is that each Dominion is entitled to assess an assessee on the total income in the normal way but it has to allow an abatement subject to the conditions mentioned in the agreement being satisfied.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ce of double taxation of income was entered into between the Government of the Dominion of India and the Government of the Dominion of Pakistan. The f

arguments.court_reasoning: Opening sentence of Art. IV shows assessment regardless of Agreement; Schedule for calculating abatement only; Art. VI procedure confirms; no certificate produced so abatement inoperative

arguments.claim: Initiation of proceedings under s.34 academic due to Commissioner not appealing High Court judgment on supplementary question

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to discuss the first question, which raises the point of the validity of proceedings under s. 34 of the Act, because it is common ground that it has become academic.

arguments.claim: High Court right on question 2 following precedent in Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Shanti K. Maheshwari

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had followed its earlier judgment in the Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City v. Shanti K. Maheshwari 1 . We hold that the High Court was right in answering this question against the Assessee A.

arguments.claim: s.49AA and Indo-Pakistan Agreement allow full assessment but abatement on excess per Art. IV, VI and Schedule if certificate produced

anchor.surface_text: Section 49AA was in the following terms The Central Government may enter into an agreement with Pakistan... It seems to us that the opening sentence of Art. IV of the Agreement that each Dominion is entitled to make assessment in the ordinary way under its own laws clearly shows that each Dominion can make an assessment regardless of the Agreement.

arguments.claim: High Court's view in Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau that resolution created contingent liability wrong as dissented by this Court in J. Dalmia v. CIT

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gupte, the learned Additional Solicitor-General, has urged that this view is wrong but that in view of the recent decision of this Court in J. Dalmia v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Delhi 2 , it is not necessary to decide this point as this Court had dissented from the decision in Commissioner of Income Tax v. Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau 1

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide in view of Dalmia

arguments.claim: Other moiety of dividend credited within meaning of s.16(2) based on P&L debit of total dividend and credits to dividend account, tax reserve etc.

anchor.surface_text: He said that the profit and loss Account of the Company was debited with Rs. 5,85,000, that being the total amount of dividend declared. The corresponding credits, he points out, were given as follows To seventh Dividend Account being the amount payable to shareholders Rs. 5,74,144-4-0

arguments.court_reasoning: Dividend credited only if unconditionally available to shareholder per Dalmia; here not credited to assessee's separate account so shareholder could not draw it

arguments.claim: Pakistan portion of dividend not credited or paid within meaning of s.16(2)

holdings.text: It is not necessary to discuss the first question, which raises the point of the validity of proceedings under s. 34 of the Act, because it is common ground that it has become academic.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to discuss the first question, which raises the point of the validity of proceedings under s. 34 of the Act, because it is common ground that it has become academic.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground between parties as Commissioner did not appeal High Court's judgment dated April 14, 1960 on supplementary question.

holdings.text: The Pakistan portion of the dividend forms part of the assessee's total income as defined in s. 2(15) of the Act; the High Court was right in answering this question against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the second question, Mr. Viswanatha Sastri rightly concedes that the Pakistan portion of the dividend forms part of the assessees total income, as defined in s. 2 15 of the Act. The High Court had followed its earlier judgment in the Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City v. Shanti K. Maheshwari 1 . We hold that the High Court was right in answering this question against the Assessee A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counsel for assessee concedes point; High Court followed its precedent in CIT v. Shanti K. Maheshwari which Supreme Court upholds.

holdings.text: Having regard to the Indo-Pakistan Agreement, the assessee is not entitled to any relief on the Pakistan portion of dividend income; answer to question is in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The next question involves the interpretation of s. 49AA of the Act, as it existed at the relevant time, and the Indo- Pakistan Agreement dated December 10, 1947. Mr. Sastri contends ... We agree with the High Court that the answer to this question is in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement under s.49AA and Art.IV permits each Dominion to assess in ordinary way under own laws without limit on assessment power but only on tax retention via abatement calculated per Schedule if certificate from other Dominion produced under Art.VI; no certificate produced so abatement inoperative and full tax payable.

holdings.text: The other moiety (Pakistan portion) of the dividend has not been credited or paid within the meaning of s. 16(2) of the Income Tax Act; answer to question D is in the negative.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Following J. Dalmia v. CIT, dividend deemed paid or credited only when company makes amount unconditionally available to shareholder; here dividend not credited to assessee's separate account and remained in general dividend account conditional on Pakistan remittances.

precedents.cited_proposition: In general, dividend may be said to be paid within the meaning of s. 16(2) when the Company discharges its liability and makes the amount of dividend unconditionally available to the member entitled thereto. This condition must also be fulfilled in case a dividend is credited
precedents.cited_holding: dividend may be said to be paid within the meaning of s. 16(2) when the Company discharges its liability and makes the amount of dividend unconditionally available to the member entitled thereto. This condition must also be fulfilled in case a dividend is credited. In other words, the credit must be in such form that the dividend is unconditionally available to the member

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the second question, Mr. Viswanatha Sastri rightly concedes that the Pakistan portion of the dividend forms part of the assessees total income, as defined in s. 2 15 of the Act. The High Court had followed its earlier judgment in the Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City v. Shanti K. Maheshwari 1 . We hold that the High Court was right in answering this question against the Assessee A.
In the result, all the appeals fail.

anchor.surface_text: The next question involves the interpretation of s. 49AA of the Act, as it existed at the relevant time, and the Indo- Pakistan Agreement dated December 10, 1947. Mr. Sastri contends ... We agree with the High Court that the answer to this question is in the negative.
In the result, all the appeals fail.
